An enlarged liver_1:
Patient Description 1:
    A 42-year-old male patient presented with persistent, dull abdominal pain localized in the upper right quadrant, rated 4/10 on the pain scale, accompanied by a sensation of heaviness. The pain has been ongoing for the past two months and is occasionally associated with nausea and vomiting, further exacerbating his fatigue. The patient has also noticed a progressive yellowing of his skin and the whites of his eyes. Notably, he has a history of travel to regions endemic for hepatitis viruses. Preliminary blood tests have indicated elevated liver enzyme levels, warranting a comprehensive evaluation to identify the underlying cause of his symptoms.
An enlarged liver_2:
Patient Description 2:
    A 55-year-old female patient with a history of chronic hepatitis B infection presented with an intermittent, sharp abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, peaking at 6/10 on the pain scale. The pain is often accompanied by persistent fatigue and occasional episodes of nausea and vomiting. The patient has observed a concerning yellowing of her skin and the whites of her eyes, indicative of jaundice. Despite prior antiviral treatments for hepatitis B, her current symptoms, including the newly developed jaundice, necessitate a thorough assessment to determine the etiology of her deteriorating liver condition.
An enlarged liver_3:
Patient Description 3:
    A 38-year-old male patient, with no significant medical history, reported a persistent, aching abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant, rated at 5/10 on the pain scale. The pain is frequently associated with fatigue, and he has experienced episodes of nausea and vomiting. The patient also noted a progressive yellowing of his skin and eyes. There is no history of viral hepatitis or recent travel. Initial investigations revealed elevated liver enzyme levels, prompting the need for further diagnostic assessments to identify the underlying cause of his enlarged liver and the associated symptoms.
